etymologies: Old English strīcan ‘go, flow’ and ‘rub lightly’, of West Germanic origin; related to German streichen ‘to stroke’, also to stroke. The sense ‘deliver a blow’ dates from Middle English

definitions: hit forcibly and deliberately with one's hand or a weapon or other implement

examples.text: he raised his hand, as if to strike me
one man was struck on the head with a stick
Edgar struck out at her

shortDefinitions: hit forcibly and deliberately with one's hand or weapon or other implement

definitions: inflict (a blow)

examples.text: the armies assembled but never struck a blow
he struck her two blows on the leg

shortDefinitions: inflict

definitions: accidentally hit (a part of one's body) against something

examples.text: she fell, striking her head against the side of the boat

shortDefinitions: accidentally hit part of one's body against something

definitions: come into forcible contact or collision with

examples.text: he was struck by a car on Whitepark Road

shortDefinitions: come into forcible contact or collision with

definitions: (of a beam or ray of light or heat) fall on (an object or surface)

examples.text: the light struck her ring, reflecting off the diamond

shortDefinitions: fall on

definitions: (in sporting contexts) hit or kick (a ball) so as to score a run, point, or goal

examples.text: he struck the ball into the back of the net

shortDefinitions: hit or kick

definitions: produce (a musical note) by pressing or hitting a key.
shortDefinitions: produce musical note by pressing or hitting key

definitions: (of a disaster, disease, or other unwelcome phenomenon) occur suddenly and have harmful or damaging effects on

examples.text: an earthquake struck the island
tragedy struck when he was killed in a car crash
storm-struck areas

shortDefinitions: occur suddenly and have harmful or damaging effects on

definitions: carry out an aggressive or violent action, typically without warning

examples.text: it was eight months before the murderer struck again

shortDefinitions: carry out aggressive or violent action

definitions: cause (someone) to be in a specified state

examples.text: he was struck dumb

shortDefinitions: cause someone to be in specified state

definitions: (of a thought or idea) come into the mind of (someone) suddenly or unexpectedly

examples.text: a disturbing thought struck Melissa

shortDefinitions: come into mind of someone suddenly or unexpectedly

definitions: cause (someone) to have a particular impression

examples.text: it struck him that Marjorie was unusually silent
the idea struck her as odd

shortDefinitions: cause someone to have particular impression

definitions: find particularly interesting, noticeable, or impressive

examples.text: Lucy was struck by the ethereal beauty of the scene

shortDefinitions: find particularly interesting or impressive

definitions: (of a clock) indicate the time by sounding a chime or stroke

examples.text: the church clock struck twelve

shortDefinitions: indicate time by sounding chime or stroke

definitions: ignite (a match) by rubbing it briskly against an abrasive surface

examples.text: the match went out and he struck another

shortDefinitions: ignite match by rubbing it briskly against abrasive surface

definitions: produce (fire or a spark) as a result of friction

examples.text: his iron stick struck sparks from the pavement

shortDefinitions: produce fire or spark as result of friction

definitions: bring (an electric arc) into being

examples.text: heat is generated by an electric arc struck between two graphitic electrodes

shortDefinitions: bring electric arc into being

definitions: (of employees) refuse to work as a form of organized protest, typically in an attempt to obtain a particular concession or concessions from their employer

examples.text: workers may strike over threatened job losses

shortDefinitions: (of employees) refuse to work as form of organized protest

definitions: undertake an organized protest against (an employer)

examples.text: photoengravers voted to strike the New York Times

shortDefinitions: undertake strike action against

definitions: cancel, remove, or cross out with or as if with a pen

examples.text: strike his name from the list
striking words through with a pen

shortDefinitions: cancel, remove, or cross out with or as if with pen

definitions: make (a coin or medal) by stamping metal

examples.text: they struck similar medals on behalf of the Normandy veterans

shortDefinitions: make coin or medal by stamping metal

definitions: (in cinematography) make (another print) of a film

examples.text: the film was reissued on a new print struck from the old negative

shortDefinitions: (in cinematography) make another print of film

definitions: reach, achieve, or agree to (something involving agreement, balance, or compromise)

examples.text: the team has struck a deal with a sports marketing agency
you have to strike a happy medium

shortDefinitions: reach, achieve, or agree to

definitions: (in financial contexts) reach (a figure) by balancing an account

examples.text: last year's loss was struck after allowing for depreciation of 67 million dollars

shortDefinitions: (in financial contexts) reach figure by balancing account

definitions: form (a committee)

examples.text: the government struck a committee to settle the issue

shortDefinitions: form

definitions: discover (gold, minerals, or oil) by drilling or mining

examples.text: if they do strike oil, there will be another test well in a year's time

shortDefinitions: discover gold, minerals, or oil by drilling or mining

definitions: come to or reach

examples.text: several days out of the village, we struck the Gilgit Road

shortDefinitions: come to or reach

definitions: move or proceed vigorously or purposefully

examples.text: she struck out into the lake with a practiced crawl
he struck off down the track

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move or proceed vigorously or purposefully

definitions: take down (a tent or the tents of an encampment)

examples.text: it took ages to strike camp

shortDefinitions: take down

definitions: dismantle (theatrical scenery)

examples.text: the minute we finish this evening, they'll start striking the set

shortDefinitions: dismantle

definitions: lower or take down (a flag or sail), especially as a salute or to signify surrender

examples.text: the ship struck her German colors

shortDefinitions: lower flag

definitions: insert (a cutting of a plant) in soil to take root

examples.text: best results are obtained from striking them in a propagator

shortDefinitions: insert cutting of plant in soil to take root

definitions: (of a plant or cutting) develop roots

examples.text: small conifers will strike from cuttings

shortDefinitions: (of plant or cutting) develop roots

definitions: (of a young oyster) attach itself to a bed

examples.text: there is no better surface for the spat to strike on than another oyster

shortDefinitions: (of young oyster) attach itself to bed

definitions: secure a hook in the mouth of a fish by jerking or tightening the line after it has taken the bait or fly.
shortDefinitions: secure hook in mouth of fish by jerking or tightening line after it has taken bait or fly

phrases.text: strike while the iron is hot

definitions: a refusal to work organized by a body of employees as a form of protest, typically in an attempt to gain a concession or concessions from their employer

examples.text: dockers voted for an all-out strike
local government workers went on strike
strike action

shortDefinitions: refusal to work organized by body of employees as form of protest

definitions: a refusal to do something expected or required, typically by a body of people, with a similar aim

examples.text: a rent strike

shortDefinitions: organized refusal to do something expected or required, with similar aim

definitions: a sudden attack, typically a military one

examples.text: the threat of nuclear strikes

shortDefinitions: sudden attack

definitions: (in bowling) an act of knocking down all the pins with one's first ball.
shortDefinitions: (in tenpin bowling) act of knocking down all pins with one's first ball

definitions: an act or instance of jerking or tightening the line to secure a fish that has already taken the bait or fly.
shortDefinitions: act or instance of jerking or tightening line to secure fish that has already taken bait or fly

definitions: a discovery of gold, minerals, or oil by drilling or mining

examples.text: the Lena goldfields strike of 1912

shortDefinitions: discovery of gold, minerals, or oil by drilling or mining

definitions: a pitch that is counted against the batter, in particular one that the batter swings at and misses, or that passes through the strike zone without the batter swinging, or that the batter hits foul (unless two strikes have already been called). A batter accumulating three strikes is out.
shortDefinitions: batter's unsuccessful attempt to hit pitched ball

definitions: a pitch that passes through the strike zone and is not hit.
shortDefinitions: pitch that passes through strike zone

definitions: something to one's discredit

examples.text: when they returned from Vietnam they had two strikes against them

shortDefinitions: something to one's discredit

definitions: the horizontal or compass direction of a stratum, fault, or other geological feature.
shortDefinitions: horizontal or compass direction of stratum

phrases.text: strike while the iron is hot
